Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Development of and Broad-Based Materials Research with the Next Generation Nanomechanical Testing Laboratory
Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-technical:
The objective of this project is to push the frontier of nanomechanical science to new horizons by developing the next generation nanomechanical testing laboratory and using it to advance fundamental understanding of materials behavior in several key scientific areas. Four core scientific studies are planned by team members from several different academic institutions. These are: (1) a fundamental study of the mechanisms of deformation that often produce enormous strength when the size of an engineering material is reduced to the sub-micrometer and nanometer scales; (2) nano-scale mechanical studies of geophysical materials as they relate to and control large-scale geophysical phenomena like earthquakes; (3) scientific factors limiting the performance of materials used for sustainable energy conversion and storage in advanced fuel cells; and (4) the unusual mechanisms of deformation and fracture in bulk metallic glasses, a relatively new class of engineering materials with unique properties not achievable in ordinary metals. In addition to the four core studies, an extended team of research partners from nine academic institutions and a national laboratory has been assembled to develop and use the system for a variety of other cutting edge materials research activities in areas as diverse as advanced batteries, welding, micro-electro-mechanical systems, additive manufacturing, protective ceramic coatings, space power systems, and two-dimensional sheet structures. The research and development partners support numerous PhD students and postdocs who will use the instrument in their research. To facilitate these interactions, summer workshops are planned to provide basic operational instruction for the graduate students and postdocs as well as summer research experiences for undergraduates. A key industrial partner will commercialize the technology.

Technical:
The nanomechanical testing laboratory, which can be used for nanoindentation, nano-compression, and nano-tensile testing, is based on several new technologies and capabilities not available on any other instrument in the world. These include: highly localized electrical resistance heating for very high temperature testing up to 1100C in high vacuum or in controlled gaseous environments; a revolutionary laser interferometric displacement measurement system with sub-nanometer resolution that eliminates longstanding problems caused by thermal drift and load frame compliance; fast Fourier signal analyzers for high speed data acquisition and feedback control at rates in the MHz range to address many unanswered but timely questions about rate effects on material behavior; unprecedented sample positioning and alignment made possible through long working distance optical systems and five independent piezo motion actuators to maximize alignment and targeting capability; and high rate testing for rapid property mapping. Many other cutting-edge design elements are also incorporated in the design. Effective integration of system components and subsystems is greatly facilitated by the collective expertise of the broad range of scientists and engineers on the team who have special skills and expertise in materials science, mechanical engineering, physics, chemistry and geology. When fully developed, the system will be operated as a national shared user facility in the Texas A&M Materials Characterization Facility (MCF).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this MRI development project is to push the frontier of nanomechanical science to new horizons by developing the next generation nanomechanical testing system and using it to advance our fundamental understanding of materials behavior in several key scientific areas. To this end, we designed, developed, and constructed a new testing instrument that can be used to measure and study the strength of materials at very small scales (down to nanometers) and at very high temperatures (up to 1100 C). The instrument was developed in two phases that focused separately on two important new technologies. In Phase I, components for heating the specimen and the indenter tip separately but very precisely were developed. Precision control of temperature is needed to assure that measurements of displacement are not influenced by thermal expansion and contraction in the testing apparatus that produce measurement errors due to "thermal drift". The Phase I system was successfully developed about half way through the program and then used with researchers from other universities to advance our understanding of small-scale mechanical behavior in several key areas. For the Phase II system, the capacitive gauge used in the Phase I instrument to measure displacement was replaced by unique laser interferometer that not only improves the measurement resolution to the 10 picometer range, but also increases the rate at which displacement can be measured to more than a million data points per second. This unique combination of high temperature and high data rate testing opens a number of new horizons for future nanomechanical scientific studies. Assembly of the Phase II instrument was completed by our development partners at KLA Nanomechanics in August 2020, and the instrument was installed at Texas A&M in September.

In addition to instrument development, a number of fundamental scientific studies were undertaken during the grant period with our research partners from several other academic institutions. Many of these focused on small-scale time-dependent plastic deformation often referred to as "creep". Our own PhD students and postdoctoral associates were pivotal in developing several new techniques for measuring creep by nanoindentation methods. These included special new techniques to mitigate thermal drift issues, development of an understanding of the importance of crystal orientation on creep, and development of a simple new model for indentation creep that allows nanoindentation creep measurements to be directly converted into conventionally measured creep parameters. Using these new ideas and techniques, our research partners from Carnegie Mellon University then used the Phase I system for a comprehensive study of the creep behavior of a new nickel-tungsten alloy that holds great promise for application as a high strength material in MEMS technology (micro-electro-mechanical systems). Our own students used the new systems to characterize the creep behavior of a solid acid material, CsHSO4, used in fuel cells, as well as several materials for application as anodes in high capacity batteries. In service, all these materials are often used in thin film form, which requires small-scale testing methods to probe their strength, and since they often heat up in service, their performance is often limited by creep. Other significant studies were undertaken by our partners from the University of Pennsylvania, Bucknell University, and Johns Hopkins University. The Pennsylvania group used the new systems and techniques to probe the nanomechanical behavior of several geological materials that are important in understanding earthquake fault friction. The Bucknell group employed the high data acquisition rates possible with the new technologies to improve our understanding of the basic processes that control the deformation of metallic glasses, a promising new class of engineering alloys with wide-ranging applications from aerospace to biomedical. Our partners at Johns Hopkins studied the mechanisms of small-scale plastic deformation in a new class nickel-molybdenum-tungsten alloys that exhibit unusually high strength. Curiously, this work was a direct spin-off of training the Johns Hopkins graduate student received at our Nanoindentation Summer Camps. Held during the summers of 2017 and 2018, these week-long camps provided graduate students and postdocs with instruction on the operation of the new testing system as well as the basic principles underlying nanoindentation and small scale mechanical behavior.

This program will have numerous long term benefits through the new technologies and products made possible by the new nanomechanical testing system and the research and development programs that follow from it. These benefits will be achieved largely through the discovery of new materials and processing techniques that will lead to new generations of engineering materials with superlative properties. Amongst the general areas in which we envision direct benefit are: faster and smaller microelectronics; greener and more efficient energy production, storage, and conversion; new biomedical devices for improved healthcare; new metals, alloys and ceramics for with improved strength for application in extreme environments; and a wide array of products that can potentially be made by additive manufacturing.
